claim.text: Li et al. (2007) documented that forest walks increased natural killer cell activity, with effects measurable seven days later
claim.claim: Li et al. (2007) documented forest walks increased natural killer cell activity with effects lasting seven days

results.summary: Li et al. published research in 2007 documenting that forest bathing (shinrin-yoku) increased natural killer cell activity with effects lasting approximately 7 days.
results.detail: Dr. Qing Li and colleagues at Nippon Medical School in Tokyo published research on forest bathing and immune function. Their 2007 study in the International Journal of Immunopathology and Pharmacology examined the effects of a forest bathing trip on human immune function, finding increased NK cell activity that persisted for at least 7 days after the forest visit. The study attributed this partly to phytoncides (wood essential oils) released by trees.
sources: Li Q et al. (2007) 'Forest bathing enhances human natural killer activity and expression of anti-cancer proteins' International Journal of Immunopathology and Pharmacology - based on training knowledge, unable to verify via live search
